Potential takeover process ongoing.

urls.title: Phillips, Fofana express sadness over migrant worker death 'tragedy'
urls.description: England midfielder Kalvin Phillips has expressed his sadness at the death of a migrant worker during the World Cup in Qatar, while France’s Youssouf Fofana has called it a “tragedy”. The Athletic revealed on Wednesday that a man died while performing repairs at the resort used as a...

tweets.text:
England midfielder Kalvin Phillips has expressed his sadness at the death of a migrant worker during the World Cup in Qatar, while France’s Youssouf Fofana has called it a “tragedy”.

https://t.co/7o04Wpf0Kw

@mjshrimper Yes Matt I can count, multiply, and divide. The point is worker deaths have occurred in every country during 2022. Yet worker deaths outside Qatar are not mentioned or reported by the press. Why?
Ans: Lazy reporters using Qatar & the WC as click bait???

FIFA and Qatar have tried to 'seize the narrative' from negative stories consuming the World Cup.

On the latest episode, @AdamCrafton_, @mjshrimper, @lmwilliamson7 and @AdamLeventhal make sure that doesn't happen.

🎙️ 𝗧𝗛𝗘 𝗔𝗧𝗛𝗟𝗘𝗧𝗜𝗖 𝗙𝗢𝗢𝗧𝗕𝗔𝗟𝗟 𝗣𝗢𝗗𝗖𝗔𝗦𝗧

@mjshrimper #FIFAWorldCup #BBCWorldCup The US experienced 4,764 work related fatalities in 2021. And 73 deaths from work related gun violence. Yet the press does not focus on these tragedies like they do worker deaths in Qatar. BTW the UK experienced 1720 work related deaths from 2010-2020.

@mjshrimper @AdamCrafton_ this happened in a hotel? As a journalist, have you done analysis of work place deaths during other tournaments compared to this one? And if not, why? I understand the migrant worker issue but the cause is losing credibility…an answer would be appreciated

urls.title: Qatar World Cup chief says migrant worker death is 'natural part of life'
urls.description: The 2022 Qatar World Cup’s chief executive Nasser Al Khater responded to a question about a recent migrant worker casualty by telling reporters that “death is a natural part of life”. urls.title: FIFA want us to see the light - but World Cup in Qatar remains under a dark shadow
urls.description: Even if the football has been a success - off-pitch events, including another death of a migrant worker, leave the World Cup under a shadow

tweets.text:
"How's Qatar?" people ask.

Well ...

I've seen some great football. Stadiums stunning! Lovely food! Friendly people! Everything so convenient for journalists.

But ... there are so many "buts". They mustn't be ignored just because we're having a nice time https://t.co/ShKK5gy1Ug

Mauricio Pochettino, the only man to have managed Harry Kane and Kylian Mbappe, on the two men who could decide England vs France on Saturday.

"Kane needs to be connected with the game. Kylian is the opposite. If he doesn't touch the ball, he’s relaxed."

#ENGFRA | #FIFAWorldCup

urls.title: Fifa accused of being ‘complicit’ in ‘human rights travesty’
urls.description: The family of World Cup whistleblower Abdullah Ibhais has called on the governing body to use its leverage to push for a fair trial

tweets.text:
Family of jailed whistleblower Abdullah Ibhais accuse Fifa and Infantino of “callous indifference” and being “complicit” in a “human rights travesty”, which is “tearing apart” his young family

Ibhais’s case was referred on Wed to a team of UN experts

https://t.co/AUolIt2aiL

For under-30s only: if someone is described as "a blancmange", does this mean anything to you?
Qatar has reportedly spent $300bn in the 12 years since it won the rights to host the men’s World Cup. It only expects the tournament to inject $17bn back into its economy

urls.title: Migrant worker died in accident on World Cup base during group stage
urls.description: Filipino man fell working on Saudi team base in incident that was covered up and highlights the continual concerns over working conditions

tweets.text:
An @TheAthleticFC investigation: 

A Filipino migrant worker died during the World Cup group stage at Saudi Arabia’s training resort in Qatar. He suffered a fatal blow to the head after a fall in a forklift accident.  

Read: https://t.co/eU08RNRJl3

A migrant worker has died during the World Cup while performing repairs at the hotel used as Saudi Arabia's FIFA training base.

The worker fell when asked to fix the lights in a car park. The government is investigating.

Report by @AdamCrafton_
.@karachikhatmal's 🐐Germany clip, with English subtitles. It's too good to be limited to a desi audience. https://t.co/6NWKml1Kfe

Becoming a little odd and pretty classist this idea that a lack of alcohol availability here equals virtue. It’s been fine here without but is often fine too with alcohol. The majority of people who travel to watch sports don’t turn into degenerates at the first sight of booze.

urls.title: Morocco are striking back for rest of the world against Europe and South America
urls.description: On and off the pitch, the Moroccans are making their presence felt in Qatar - they fully deserve their place in the World Cup quarter-finals

tweets.text: The first fortnight of this World Cup was about the underdogs. Then the old established order (Europe, South America) struck back, so Morocco’s dramatic, defiant victory over Spain is one to savour — and huge for Africa and the Arab world #Morocco 🇲🇦 #MAR https://t.co/UbCdcU1w4U

urls.title: A Beer Run in Qatar, and an Oasis That Isn’t Open to All
urls.description: At the only government-sanctioned store selling alcohol during the World Cup, strict rules keep it out of reach for most residents.

urls.title: Rice says World Cup rivals ‘should fear England’ ahead of France clash
urls.description: Declan Rice has said that other countries “should be starting to fear us now” ahead of England’s quarter-final against France on Saturday. England overcame a sluggish start to beat Senegal 3-0 on Sunday evening, with clinical finishes applied by Jordan Henderson, Harry Kane, and Bukayo Saka.

tweets.text: 🚨 Declan Rice on #ENG: “Don’t think we’ve been getting credit we deserve. Others win comfortably & called masterclasses. With us it always gets picked off. Last couple of games faultless. Countries should start to fear us now” @TheAthleticFC #FIFAWorldCup https://t.co/95ZszD9Ctc
